basics.name: Anh Ho
basics.label: PhD Candidate in Computer Science
basics.summary: I am deeply passionate about leveraging automated solutions to address challenges in Software Engineering.

education.studyType: Doctor of Philosophy - Engineering and IT

education.institution: Hanoi University of Science and Technology - HUST
courses: Thesis title: Deep learning for automated detection of code smells
Selected for Talented Program in Computer Science (Selected 35 out of 1000 in our cohorts)

work.name: Software Engineering Research Group, The University of Melbourne
highlights: Exploring the concept of regression errors and software debugging while also conducting a comprehensive survey and analysis of identifying, finding, repairing, and testing strategies related to regression errors

work.name: Intelligent Software Engineering Laboratory - RISE, BK-AI, HUST
work.summary: Topic: Software Defect Prediction and Code Smell Detection
highlights: Supervisor: Dr. Mai-Anh Bui (Research Leader of ISE Research Group)
Collaborating with Dr. Thanh-Phuong Nguyen (The University of L’Aquila, Italy), who has been my co-supervisor since October 2022

awards.summary: The top 40 candidates have been selected to participate in the Vietnam Team Selection Test 2019 (VN TST 2019), with the aim of choosing the top 6 students to represent the national team at the International Mathematical Olympiad 2019 (IMO 2019)

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
